prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request 2 ALMA pointings, each consisting of two quasi-simultaneous observations in bands 3 and 6 to be taken at two different X-ray luminosity according to our already approved multi-wavelength monitoring. We expect to sample a radio/mm flux variation of ~2 orders of magnitudes.
With an inverted radio spectra (index of $\alpha$ = 0.0--0.5), the 9 GHz flux densities of compact jets can range from few tenths of mJy to tens of mJy (Corbel et al. 2000, 2003, Fender 2001; Fig. 3) giving an estimated 100 to 250 GHz flux density of 0.5 to 60 mJy. It is necessary to reach a r.m.s. level of the order of 0.1 mJy for the brightest observation, and a r.m.s. of 0.05 mJy for the one taken at fainter level in order to achieve a more than 5-10$\sigma$ detection in the less favorable case, and constrain the mm spectral shape itself. We note that the two different ALMA bands need to be executed sequentially in order to have a reasonable mm spectral index. In any case, the observations will stop, once our r.m.s. noise level would have been achieved.

In order to follow the evolution of the radio-mm spectral index with the accretion rate during the outburst, we propose to observe the selected source with a series of 2 ALMA observations, to be taken at two different X-ray luminosity, according to our already approved multi-wavelength monitoring. Each ALMA observation consists in obtaining short quasi-simultaneous observations of the continuum emission at two different millimeter wavelengths (bands 3 and 6). TDM continuum mode is used to maximise the sensitivity.

Based on the recurrence time of SXTs, we estimate that these ToO observations could be triggered once a year, as an average of two bright X-ray outbursts are observed per year. Our observations must be performed during the hard state of a BHXB in outburst because the presence of the compact jet is required (the compact jets are quenched in the Soft state, Corbel et al. 2000). As shown in Figure 1 (see proposals for figure), for a given outburst, two hard state periods are available for observations and each period can last for several months.
The proposed mm observations will be triggered when our radio and/or X-ray monitoring indicate that a BHXB is in the hard state (based on the spectral/ timing properties). Triggering from radio and/or X-ray observations has been proven to be a very reliable method, as the data are quickly available (e.g. Tomsick et al. 2008). After notification of a ToO event, the first ALMA observation could be scheduled with a delay of more than 2 weeks as the hard state can last several months. In case of positive detection, we would like to have the second ALMA observation scheduled (schedules permitting) after at least 3 weeks in order to have a significant flux variation (Fig. 3). With a total time (including overheads) of about 20-25 minutes per ALMA band and a slow reaction time, our ToO observation could easily be introduced in the schedule with limited impact.

Our target (any BHXB in outburst) will be unresolved and will therefore be a point source in all ALMA bands with any of the ALMA configurations. No map will be needed and observation could be conducted as single pointing observations in any available configuration (even with the limited u-v coverage resulting from the few minutes integration time).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
In Galactic X-ray binaries, an enormous amount of energy is harnessed to produce powerful relativistic jets. The engine for jet production is a compact object surrounded by an accretion disk, but the production mechanism and many of the jet properties are subjects of debate.
In order to constrain the physical mechanisms involved in jet production, we propose Target of Opportunity observations of black hole X-ray binaries in outburst with ALMA. We aim to catch the hard spectral state, corresponding to the unique period when their powerful compact jets are building up. Our objectives are to determine the contribution of the jets to total energetics of the system with ALMA and with already accepted quasi simultaneous observations in radio, optical-infrared, X-ray (Swift, Integral, Suzaku, NuSTAR) and up to very high energy (Fermi). ALMA is the only telescope able to bridge the gap between the radio and infrared frequency ranges with very limited observing time.
